iati-activity.description: The overall objective is to improve public health and environmental integrity throughout urban and peri-urban areas of Ghana through the provision of reliable and complete sanitation. iati-activity.title: Particle Board Manufacturing
iati-activity.description: ISSUE: The construction contract was awarded in June 1986, with a completion period of 24 months and supervision was awarded on 5th March 1986. The work physically commenced on 1st September 1986. The contractor was suspended in 1989 in order to allow Government investigation of the course of the failed sections of the road. The contract was eventually terminated. The project remains nearly 60% completed with UA 13.44 million disbursed. There have not been any disbursements since 9th March 1989. The Government has confirmed that the dispute between the Government and Messrs. ABU and Partners has been resolved with no legal or financial obligations to the Bank. On 18th December 1997, the Government requested Bank's approval to revise the list of works and services with a view to completing the project by utilizing the remaining UA 10.23 million. The Bank approved the Government's request on 19th April 1999, with the revised deadline for final disbursement being 31st December 2002. Since the approval of the revised list of works and services, the Government has entered into contract with a consulting firm for the design review, pre-tender activities and supervision of works. The draft tender documents are currently being reviewed by the Bank. However, the pre-qualifying contractors is completed. However, the Government has been very slow in implementing the project. ACTION: The Government should speed up the procurement process. The Bank's mission that is scheduled for early March will conclude the review of the tender Documents with the Government.

contact-info.mailing-address: African Development Bank Group AfDB Temporary Relocation Agency (Tunis) 15 Avenue du Ghana P.O.Box 323-1002 Tunis-Belvedère, Tunisia or Statutory Headquarters Rue Joseph Anoma, 01 BP 1387 Abidjan 01 Côte d'Ivoire

iati-activity.title: Health Services Rehabilitation II
iati-activity.description: 1. Overall Objective: ----------------- The major objective of the project is the improvement of the standard of health care services available in the country through the strategic rehabilitation of training and referral hospitals, strengthening of hospital maintenance and management systems and support to the expanded programme on immunization (EPI). 2. Specific Objectives: ------------------- (i) raise the physical conditions and managerial standards of the country's two teaching hospitals at Accra and Kumasi and the regional referral hospital at Sekondi/Takoradi so as to permit their efficient and sanitary functioning and better utilize the scarce, highly skilled professionals who staff them; (ii) establish sound systems for the maintenance of the hospitals and all equipment and for the general and financial management of the hospitals, which will serve as examples to the trainees who will pass through them; and (iii) raise the level of child immunization against six major diseases to achieve 80% coverage by 1992.

iati-activity.title: Poverty Reduction
iati-activity.description: The overall objective of the project is to contribute signficantly to reducing rural and urban poverty in Ghana. It will support the establishment of a Social Investment Fund (SIF) to achieve the following specific objectives: (i) facilitate access of the poor to basic economic and social infrastructures, such as schools and health centers, and services; (ii) enhance the access of the poor to financial services, especially by increasing the availability of micro-finance and the capacity of micro-finance institutions; and, (iii) strengthen community-based organizations (CBOs), non-governmental organizations (NGOs), indigenous micro-finance institutions (MFIs), and local Government administrations in support of the overall goal of poverty reduction.

iati-activity.title: Urban Poverty Reduction Project
iati-activity.description: The overall project objective is to contribute to Ghana#s efforts to achieving the MDG that calls for a reduction by half of the proportion of poor living on less than a dollar a day through urban poverty reduction strategies. Specific project objectives are to (i) Develop poor urban settlements through participatory management, job creation and strengthened public/private partnership and local governance and management capacity; (ii) Improve livelihoods in urban and peri-urban zones through increased access to basic quality services and socioeconomic infrastructure; (iii) Facilitate access to income generating activities through capacity building and strengthened urban small-scale enterprise sector.

iati-activity.title: Eco. Reform Support Loan II (Erso II)
iati-activity.description: The ADF loan will seek to consolidate the gains in restoring macroeconomic stability under the economic reform programme of the first Economic Reform Support Operation (ERSO I) loan, support the continued implementation of structural reforms including good governance and decentralization. The reform measures to be supported by the loan are designed to: (i),,continue with reforms to improve macroeconomic stability by reducing the rate of inflation, the level of the fiscal deficit and increasing the level of foreign reserves; (ii) accelerate the implementation of structural reforms especially reforms in public revenue and expenditure management, privatisation and deepening private participation in key economic sectors, such as agriculture and energy; (iii),,implement a governance programme, which includes reforms of capacity building within the civil service, legal reforms for greater efficiency and transparency, increased popular participation and a fight against corruption; and, (iv),,decentralise decision-making by devolving power and resources to the district level.

iati-activity.title: Development of Senior Secondary Education Project (Education III Project)
iati-activity.description: The overall objective of the proposed Education III project is to contribute significantly to improving access to Senior Secondary Schools (SSS) to thousands of Ghanaian Junior Secondary School (JSS) graduates and to enhance the quality of these schools. To this end, its specific objectives are: to (i) facilitate access to Senior Secondary Schools (SSS) of thousands of Ghanaian Junior Secondary School (JSS) graduates; (ii) enhance the quality of secondary education; and (iii) strengthen the institutional management capacity and governance of the Ministry of Education at the central and decentralized levels especially with respect to establishing a centralized and computerized SSS student selection system. Special attention will be given to promoting participation of girls and less privileged pupils.

iati-activity.title: Women's Community Development Project
iati-activity.description: 1. Overall Objective: The objective of the project is to contribute to the Government's effort to create participatory self-sustaining development at the rural and local levels, with major concern given to the fuller participation of women both as participants in and beneficiaries from development initiatives. 2. Specific Objectives: (i) to increase the capacity of the target beneficiaries to earn income by providing appropriate processing equipment and training in production methods; (ii) to provide a credit facility and related management advisory to finance and support income generating activities by women's groups; (iii) to assist women in productive as well as social functions by providing social amenities, day care centers and water wells: and; (iv) to provide institutional capacity building to the institutions involved in the project (e.g. NCWD, DWM and Ghana Commercial Bank, etc.).

iati-activity.title: Private Sector Adjustment Loan
iati-activity.description: A. Issues 1.1 The emphasis on construction works and related activities at the exclusion of other project components aimed at strengthening management and maintenance capabilities has resulted in unsatisfactory project performance. 2. The inability of the government to provide counterpart funding has caused delays in the implementation of civil works and has impeded the implementation of other project components . 3. Delay in the payment of Disbursement Requests after having received ADF approval. B. Actions Taken/Results 1.1 The revised Ministry of Health proposal outlining the activities for the implementation of non-civil works components was reviewed during the mission at meetings held with the MOH and the PIU. 2.1 The Government has recently provided approximately 1.4 billion Cedis for counterpart funding which has allowed the continued implementation of non-civil works activities. C. Proposed Actions 1.1 The Ministry of Health was requested to submit information clarifying the external training proposal confirming the acceptance of candidates by the training institutions to the Bank by 1 June 1999. 2.1 The Bank should continue to monitor the level and frequency of the receipt of counterpart funding to avoid further implementation delays. 3.1 ADF should expedite the processing of Disbursement Requests to avoid causing operational delays in the implementation of the project. 3.2 The Bank should explore means of reporting disbursements by project component as well as by category.

iati-activity.title: Health Services Rehabilitation I
iati-activity.description: 1. Overall Objective: ----------------- The major objective of the project is the improvement of the standard of health care services available in the country through the strategic rehabilitation of training and referral hospitals, strengthening of hospital maintenance and management systems and support to the expanded programme on immunization (EPI). 2. Specific Objectives: ------------------- (i) raise the physical conditions and managerial standards of the country's two teaching hospitals at Accra and Kumasi and the regional referral hospital at Sekondi/Takoradi so as to permit their efficient and sanitary functioning and better utilize the scarce, highly skilled professionals who staff them; (ii) establish sound systems for the maintenance of the hospitals and all equipment and for the general and financial management of the hospitals, which will serve as examples to the trainees who will pass through them; and (iii) raise the level of child immunization against six major diseases to achieve 80% coverage by 1992.

iati-activity.title: Interconnexion Project
iati-activity.description: Major assumptions that will influence the performance of the project include that a) no adverse weather conditions prevail during the implementation period to negatively affect the productivity of the sector b) international commodity prices particularly those of cocoa and coton will not face any drastic falls c) the Government of Ghana will continue to pursue its macro and sectoral adjustment programmes to further stimulate private sector investment and d) government will not introduce new import policies that will affect the demand for the key agricultural inputs expected to be financed from the proceeds of the credit. The other area where likely risk is anticipated during the implementation of the credit are foreign exchange fluctuations or rapid depreciation of the Cedi, operational capacity limitation of the AgDB and low loan recovery rates.

iati-activity.participating-org: MINISTRY OF FINANCE AND ECONOMIC PLANNING
iati-activity.title: Poverty Reduction Support Loan II
iati-activity.description: The Second Poverty Reduction Loam (PRSL-III) will focus on three broad components of the poverty reduction agenda: (i) promotion of growth, income and employment; (ii) improvements in the delivery of services for human development; and (iii) strengthening of good governance, human resource development and public sector management. PRSL-II will also pay particular attention to policy dialogue, enhance the efficiency and transparency of public spending, and build the capacity to monitor and evaluate resource allocation and policy outcomes. It will help increase access, completion and quality of education and health care services to the deprived areas, and notably to the poor. It will also support the development of a comprehensive social protection strategy, as well as interventions to help contain the spread of HIV/AIDS.

iati-activity.title: Tertiary éducation Rehabilitation Projet (Terp)
iati-activity.description: 1. Overall Objective: The major objectives of the project are to assist the Government to put into operation its strategy for improving the quality and relevance of tertiary education, and supporting the Government's efforts to extend its primary and secondary reforms to the tertiary sector. 2. Specific Objectives: (i) to improve the physical condition of the existing facilities by completing and rehabilitating certain essential science and library buildings; (ii) to improve access to tertiary education in a cost effective way by providing day-student facilities for non-resident students; (iii) to support the Government's objective of reaching a gender ratio of approximately 50:50 by providing non-residential day facilities and other incentives for girls; (iv) to rationalize the curriculum of tertiary education in order to avoid duplication of services and to make it relevant to the manpower needs of the nation. The project provides equipment, technical assistance and training to assist in this regard; (v) to improve the quality of the teaching staff by providing technical assistance for the training programme.

iati-activity.participating-org: MINISTRY OF FINANCE AND ECONOMIC PLANNING
iati-activity.title: Institutional Support Project for Governance & Poverty Reduction
iati-activity.description: The ultimate goal of the project is to contribute to poverty reduction and achieve greater economic and social development through strengthening the human and institutional governance capacity of the state and the PRSP process in Ghana. The project will promote good governance in the areas of accountability, efficiency, transparency and anti-corruption. The project goal will be realised through strengthening the institutional and human resource capacity of the Parliamentary Service (PS), the Judicial Service (JS), the Commission for Human Rights and Administrative Justice (CHRAJ) and the National Development Planning Commission that is responsible for co-coordinating the PRSP process. The capacity building and institutional support will include providing local training, installing information technology, and providing other logistics, such as equipment.
